case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. the assessee

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 358 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 358 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 8th March, 1956, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 55 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated 8th March, 1956, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 55 of 1955.

facts.text: The respondent is a registered firm carrying on business as commission agents in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a registered firm carrying on business as companymission agents in Bombay.

facts.text: For purposes of its business it borrowed money from time to time from Banks on joint promissory notes executed by it and by others with joint and several liability.

anchor.surface_text: For purposes of its business it borrowed money from time to time from Banks on joint promissory numberes executed by it and by others with joint and several liability.

facts.text: On September 26, 1949, the respondent borrowed Rs. 1,00,000 from the Bank of India on a pronote executed jointly with one Kishorilal.

anchor.surface_text: On September 26, 1949, the respondent borrowed Rs. 1,00,000 from the Bank of India on a pronote executed jointly with one Kishorilal.

facts.text: Out of this amount a sum of Rs. 50,000 was taken by the respondent for purposes of its business and the rest by Kishorilal.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this amount a sum of Rs. 50,000 was taken by the respondent for purposes of its business and the rest by Kishorilal.

facts.text: Kishorilal failed to meet his liability and became a bankrupt.

anchor.surface_text: Kishorilal however failed to meet his liability and became a bankrupt.

facts.text: The respondent had to pay the Bank the whole amount, i.e., Rs. 1,00,000 with interest.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had therefore to pay the Bank the whole amount, i.e., Rs. 1,00,000 with interest.

facts.text: Out of the amount taken by Kishorilal the respondent received in the accounting year, from the Official Assignee, a sum of Rs. 18,805.

anchor.surface_text: Out of the amount taken by Kishorilal the respondent received in the accounting year, from the Official Assignee, a sum of Rs. 18,805 and claimed the balance, i.e., Rs. 31,740 as deduction.

facts.text: The respondent claimed the balance, i.e., Rs. 31,740 as deduction.

anchor.surface_text: ...a sum of Rs. 18,805 and claimed the balance, i.e., Rs. 31,740 as deduction.

facts.text: The accounting year was from August 26, 1949 to July 17, 1950, the assessment year being 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The accounting year was from August 26, 1949 to July 17, 1950, the assessment year being 1951-52.

facts.text: This claim was disallowed both by the Income-tax Officer as well as the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: This claim was disallowed both by the Income-tax Officer as well as the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: On Appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal this sum was allowed as an allowable deduction under s. 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act and as business loss.

anchor.surface_text: On Appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal this sum was allowed ,as an allowable deduction under s. 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act and as business loss.

facts.text: At the instance of the Commissioner a case was stated to the High Court of Bombay by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner a case was stated to the High Court of Bombay by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: In the statement of the case which was agreed to by both parties.

facts.text: The Commercial practice is to borrow money from banks on joint and several liability.

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial practice is to borrow money from banks on joint and several liability.

facts.text: Rs. 1,00,000 borrowed from the Bank was in accordance with the commercial practice of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: that Rs. 1,00,000 borrowed from the Bank was in accordance with the companymercial practice of Bombay.

facts.text: Counsel for the Commissioner challenged the findings of the Tribunal in regard to the existence of commercial practice in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the Commissioner challenged the findings of the Tribunal in regard to the existence of companymercial practice in Bombay

facts.text: Two questions of law were referred to the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts the following two questions of law were referred to the High Court- Whether the assessees claim is sustainable under section 10 2  xv  of the Act?

facts.text: Both these questions were answered in favour of the respondent and against the appellant by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: both were answered in favour of the assessee and against the Commissioner of Income-tax who is the appellant before us and the assessee is the respondent.

facts.text: The finding of the Tribunal is clear and explicit that what the assessee was doing was not something out of the ordinary, but in borrowing this money on joint and several liability he was following a practice which was established as a commercial practice.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of the Tribunal is clear and explicit that what the assessee was doing was number something out of the ordinary, but in borrowing this money on joint and several liability he was following a practice which was established as a companymercial practice.

facts.text: Banks advanced monies to some constituents on their personal security also but they had to pay a higher rate of interest than when the money was borrowed on joint and several responsibility.

anchor.surface_text: It also found that the Banks advanced monies to some companystituents on their personal security also but they had to pay a higher rate of interest than when the money was borrowed on joint and several responsibility

facts.text: The Supreme Court appeal was heard on November 24, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 24. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.

facts.text: The respondent was rightly held to be entitled to deduct the loss.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion in the circumstances proved in the present case, and on the facts established and on the findings given, the respondent was rightly held to be entitled to deduct the loss which was suffered by him in the transaction in dispute.

facts.text: There was a well recognised commercial practice in Bombay of carrying on business by borrowing money from Banks on joint and several liability.

anchor.surface_text: In the companytext this Court held that where a Nattukottai Chetti money-lender paid off in their entirety the debts jointly due by him and another as a result of the latters inability to pay, the loss sustained as a result of this transaction was a loss of the moneylending business itself and therefore a deductible item in companyputing profits.

issues.text: Whether the assessees claim is sustainable under section 10 2 xv of the Act?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessees claim is sustainable under section 10 2 xv of the Act?

issues.text: Whether the assessees claim that the loss was a business loss and, therefore, allowable as a deduction in computing the profits of the assessees business is sustainable under law?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the assessees claim that the loss was a business loss and, therefore, allowable as a deduction in computing the profits of the assessees business is sustainable under law?

issues.text: Whether there exists a commercial practice in Bombay of borrowing money from banks on joint and several liability?

anchor.surface_text: On Appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal this sum was allowed ,as an allowable deduction under s. 10 2 xv of the Income-tax Act and as business loss. At the instance of the Commissioner a case was stated to the High Court of Bombay by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal. In the statement of the case which was agreed to by both parties the Tribunal said For the purpose of his business, he borrows from time to time money on joint and several liability from banks. The Commercial practice is to borrow money from banks on joint and several liability.

issues.text: Whether mutuality is an essential ingredient of the commercial custom and was it established in this case?

anchor.surface_text: This statement of the law was approved by this Court but there mutuality, as an essential ingredient of the custom established, was found to be lacking as is shown by the following passage from the judgment of the court. The custom stated before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was that persons carrying on business in Bombay used to borrow monies on joint security from the Banks in order to facilitate getting financial assistance from the Banks and that too at lower rates of interest.

issues.text: Whether the loss of the respondent was a capital loss?
